author: afdudley
content:
Where should we discuss https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/21350, https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/21357 and https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/21358 ?

I think these are more important than 1559 at the moment and do what the public erroneously expects 1559 to do.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@332923501079953409> Are you looking for a more real-time conversation than that first issue?

author: afdudley
content: Yeah, I guess I am. I feel like there is actually a fee crisis going on and people are not super worried about it.

author: afdudley
content: I read a lot of frankly stupid arguments about free markets or whatever without realizing that our choices are what's making the system. it's not some natural phenomenon that exists without our intervention.

author: sky.cactus
content: Is there any significant pushback against FIFO in geth?

author: sky.cactus
content: From what I have seen, it sounds like people are *generally ok with it*, though some people think there are other solutions that may be better.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, I have only seen one person argue that FIFO would be *worse* than the current solution, and they dropped the argument pretty quickly.

author: sky.cactus
content: The Geth PR to add price-time ordering of transactions didn't get instantly closed like the other one, which implies to me that the maintainers are at least not against it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the only thing that would push things forward is pressuring Geth to get a release out, and then pressuring miners to switch to the new client.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless you were talking about the `atomicWith` and `dependsOn` changes, which need to wait at *least* until a hard fork, and I think the first step for them is underway already (EIP-2718).

author: sky.cactus
content: My one issue with the `atomicWith` and `dependsOn` flags is that it introduces the possibility of a circular dependency which clients will have to deal with.  Certainly not impossible to deal with, but it is complexity that would be nice to not have added to clients.

author: jgm
content:
One problem I can think of with time-based ordering is that the client is no longer free (or as free) to throw out old transactionsthat haven't been included in blocks.  Not involved enough to know if it really matters, mind.

There's also the obvious point that this is code not protocol, so more of a suggestion than a rule.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why wouldn't the client be free to throw out transactions?

author: sky.cactus
content: Agreed that this is a suggestions but we have reason to believe that this suggestion will be adopted by miners eventually and can help ethereum's gas usage.

author: jgm
content: Well it could, but then it may result in re-ordering of the transactions as they return to the mempool.  Could make it susceptible to some sort of mempool flooding attack (although again I'm not deep enough in this to know; haven't looked at the mempool code for a couple of years now).

author: afdudley
content: <@!301186049323958275> I'm more concerned with how those of us interested in protocol/client work communicate with the community at large, I think the github discussions on FIFO change have been super productive.
